projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Plea≈øant Companion: OR NEW LESSONS and INSTR∆≤CTIONS For the FLAGELET.
London, Printed for John Playford, and are to be Sold at his Shop in the Inner-Temple, near the Church. 1675.

div.head: Directions for Playing on the FLAGELET.
div.p: THe Flagelet is an In≈øtrument that may very fitly be termed a A Plea≈øant Companion, for it may be carried in the Pocket, and ≈øo without any trouble bear one company either by Land or by Water. It hath this advantage over other In≈øtruments, that it is always in Tune, which they are not: And for tho≈øe who≈øe Genius leads them to Mu≈øick, I know not a more ea≈øie and plea≈øant In≈øtrument: And though at fir≈øt it may ≈øeem difficult to Beginners, yet with the Practice of a few Hours, ob≈øerving the≈øe following Directions, and a little a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of a skilful Ma≈øter, the knowledge hereof may be readily obtained.

div.head: Of Holding the Flagelet.
div.p: THere are two ways of Holding the Flagelet u≈øually taught by the Profe≈ø≈øors on this In≈øtrument: The fir≈øt way is to hold it with the left hand next the mouth, the thumb and three fingers thereof on the four fir≈øt Holes, and the thumb and fir≈øt finger of the right hand on the two la≈øt, holding the End of the Flagelet between the ≈øecond and third finger. The ≈øecond way of Holding it (which I conceive is the be≈øt) is to hold it with the left hand next the mouth as before, but with this difference, the thumb and two fir≈øt fingers thereof ≈øtopping the three fir≈øt Holes, and the thumb and two fir≈øt fingers of the right hand ≈øtopping the three la≈øt Holes; ≈øo that as the Flagelet hath four Holes above, and two below, ≈øo they are ≈øtopt above with the four fir≈øt fingers, and beneath with the two thumbs; and for the better ≈øtaying it to ones mouth, the end of it is to be held between the third and little finger, placing the third finger above, and the little finger underneath, as is expre≈ø≈øed in the Figure before the Title.

div.head: Of the manner of playing on the Flagelet.
div.p:
ALL Tunes or Le≈ø≈øons for the Flagelet are prick'd upon ≈øix Lines, an≈øwering to the ≈øix Holes on that In≈øtrument, by certain Characters called Dots: The≈øe Dots direct what Holes are to be ≈øtopt, there being ≈øo many and the ≈øame holes to be ≈øtopt on the Flagelet each breath, as there are dots placed perpendicularly on the ≈øix Lines; as ≈øuppo≈øe a dot upon the fir≈øt or uppermo≈øt Line, the fir≈øt hole on the Flagelet (agreeing with that fir≈øt Line) mu≈øt be ≈øtopt; and if there be two dots one over another, as on the fir≈øt and ≈øecond, or fir≈øt and third Lines, then the fir≈øt and ≈øecond, or fir≈øt and third holes on the Flagelet are to be ≈øtopt: For in≈øtance, in pricking the Tune called Maiden Fair, for the two fir≈øt Sounds or Breaths is made a dot upon the fir≈øt and third Line twice over, and accordingly the fir≈øt and third hole of the Flagelet mu≈øt be ≈øtopt, and then blown gently twice. The like is to be under≈øtood of all the re≈øt; ob≈øerving, that as many rows of dots as there is from top to bottom on the ≈øix Lines, ≈øo many ≈øeveral ≈øounds mu≈øt there be on the Flagelet. Above the ≈øix Lines over the dots are placed
Notes for expre≈ø≈øing the Mea≈øure of Time, ≈ølow or ≈øwift; of which Notes or Time, I ≈øhall give you a certain Rule to know the Proportion on in its due place.

p.hi: 1st. Example of the plain Notes=A≈ø≈øending and De≈øending

div.p: Your Flagelet being held as is directed, and your fingers on the ≈øix Holes, your fir≈øt Stop or Note is 6 Dots, the ≈øecond 5, the third 4, the fourth 3, the fifth 2, the ≈øixth 2 divided, the ≈øeventh 1, the eighth a Cypher [o] which is all open. Blow gently, and take your Breath at every Note or Sound. Example of the≈øe in their order.

list.head: Directions for Playing the Eight Notes Up or A≈øcending.
list.item: 1 Blow gently, all ≈øix Holes being ≈øtopt, is 6 Dots.
2 Up with the ≈øecond finger of the right hand, is 5 Dots.
3 Off with the thumb of the right hand, is 4 Dots.
4 Up with the fir≈øt finger of the right hand, is 3 Dots.
5 Up with the ≈øecond finger of the left hand, is 2 Dots.
6 Up with the fir≈øt finger on the left hand, and down again with the ≈øecond finger, is 2 Dots divided.
7 Up with the ≈øecond finger of the left hand, is 1 Dot.
8 Off with the thumb of the left hand is the Cypher [o] upon the fir≈øt or uppermo≈øt Line, which is all open.

list.head: To Play the Eight Notes Down or De≈øcending.
list.item: 1 Blow gently all Holes being open, is the Cypher [o] upon the uppermo≈øt Line.
2 Stop with the thumb of the left hand, is 1 Dot.
3 Stop with the ≈øecond finger of the left hand, the thumb remaining, is 2 Dots divided.
4 Stop with the fir≈øt finger of the left hand, taking up the middle finger, is 2 Dots.
5 Stop with the ≈øecond finger of the left hand again, the re≈øt remaining, is 3 Dots.
6 Stop with the fir≈øt finger of the right hand, the re≈øt remaining, is 4 Dots.
7 Stop with the thumb of the right hand, is 5 Dots.
8 Stop with the ≈øecond finger of the right hand, and now all is ≈øtopt, which is 6 Dots.

div.p: Practi≈øe to Play the≈øe Eight Notes a≈øcending and de≈øcending, till you are perfect in them, always ob≈øerving this Rule, that in Notes a≈øcending gradually, you mu≈øt increa≈øe your Breath by degrees; and contrary in Notes de≈øcending, and in Notes that Ri≈øe or Fall by Skips, you mu≈øt ≈øuddenly increa≈øe or dimini≈øh your Breath, as the Notes require: The taking off a Finger rai≈øeth, and the ≈øtopping down the contrary. Always remember to ≈øtop the Holes clo≈øe, and to hit every Note di≈øtinctly with the tip of your Tongue.

In the next place is ≈øet down an Example of the Pinching Notes, as al≈øo an Example of the ≈øeveral Graces on this In≈øtrument, together with a Table
of the Notes Flat and Sharp, a≈øcending on the Violin and Flagelet: I ≈øhall ≈øay ≈øomewhat to explain the≈øe two Examples, and proceed to the Names of the Notes, their Proportions and Time.

p.hi: Example of the Pinching or higer Notas „Äà‚ô´„Äâ Notes A≈ø≈øending Notes De≈øending

div.p: 3 d. Example of ≈øhaks & Beats „Äà‚ô´„Äâ a Beat: a ≈øhak: a ≈ølur: a ≈ølur & beat.

p.hi: A Table of the Notes flat & ≈øharp A≈ø≈øending on the Violin and on the Flagilet

div.head: Of the Pinching Notes on the Flagelet.
div.p: The Pinching Notes a≈øcend eight Notes higher than the Plain Notes, and are di≈øtingui≈øhed from them by a da≈øh drawn through the fir≈øt or highe≈øt Dot, making it a Cro≈øs, as in the foregoing Example. To play it on the Flagelet you mu≈øt do thus: Bend your left thumb, and let it be but half over the fir≈øt Hole (on which the Pinch is always made, by pinching your Nail hard over half the Hole) then give it a ≈øtronger Breath than the former Notes had, and you ≈øhall find the Sound of the Flagelet to be eight Notes higher. All the other Stops are the ≈øame with the former.

div.head: Of the ≈øeveral Graces on the Flagelet.
div.p:
In the former Example of the Graces, the Mark or Character of a Beat and Shake is all one, but in playing them there is this difference: When the Mark is on the ≈øame Line even with the Dot, then you are to lift up that Finger and ≈øhake, and lay it down again before you play any other Note; this is called a Beat. But when the Mark ≈øtands alone upon any other Line underneath the Dot, then with the Finger belonging to that Line on which
it is ≈øet you mu≈øt ≈øhake, taking it off again before you play any other Note; and this is called a Shake. The third Mark or Character is for a Slur or Slide, that is, when two Notes are tyed together by a crooked da≈øh underneath, then tho≈øe two Notes are to be expre≈ø≈øed with one Breath. There is another not much unlike this, which concludes with a Beat, and is played thus: Hit the fir≈øt Note with the tip of your Tongue, and continuing your Breath, take up the ≈øecond and bring on the fir≈øt beating.

div.head: The Names of the Notes, their Proportions and Time.
div.p: THe Mood for the Common Time is thus Marked ùáç, and is multiplied by 2, as one Semibreve is two Minims, one Minim two Crotchets, one Crotchet two Quavers, &c.

If what is ≈øaid here concerning the Common Time be not ≈øufficient to in≈øtruct a Beginner, I refer him to Mr. Playford's Introduction to the Skill of Mu≈øick, where he may not only be in≈øtructed in this, and the Triple Time, but in all the Grounds of Mu≈øick, both Vocal and In≈øtrumental.
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ

The Mood for Triple Time is thus Marked ùáä3, and is multiplied by 3, (the Note having a Prick added to it) as one Minim with a Prick is three Crotchets, &c.
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ

I ≈øhall conclude all at pre≈øent with an Example directing what Key or Note any Tune prick'd for the Violin is proper for the Flagelet; in which ob≈øerve, that all Le≈ø≈øons beginning on the Violin in A re, F fa vt, C ≈øol fa, and D la ≈øol, have the ≈øame Key on the Flagelet.

div.head: BOOKS lately Printed and Sold by JOHN PLAYFORD.
div.p: THe Dancing-Ma≈øter, containing Rules for Dancing Country-Dances, with the Tunes over each Dance for the Treble-Violin. Bound 2 s. 6 d.
Mu≈øicks Recreation on the Viol Lyra-way, containing choice Le≈ø≈øons for the lone Lyra-Viol, with In≈øtructions for Beginners; newly Reprinted with large Additions. 2 s. 6 d.

Apollo's Banquet for the Treble-Violin, ≈øet forth in new Theatre Tunes, Ayres, Corants, &c. to which is added the Tunes of the new French-Dances; al≈øo Rules and Directions for Practitioners on the Treble-Violin. 1 s. 6 d.
Mu≈øicks Solace, containing Le≈ø≈øons and In≈øtructions for the Cithren; newly Printed in a more ea≈øie method than it was formerly. Bound 1 s. 6 d.
Mu≈øicks Handmaid, pre≈øenting new Le≈ø≈øons for the Virginals, fitted for the practice of young Beginners. 2 s. 6 d.
An Introduction to the Skill of Mu≈øick, both Vocal and In≈øtrumental; newly Reprinted and Enlarged. Bound 2 s.
P≈øalms and Hymns to the Common Tunes u≈øed in Pari≈øh Churches, Compo≈øed in Four Parts, in Folio; a Book far more u≈øeful than that of Mr. Raven≈øcrofts formerly publi≈øhed. 3 s.
Choice Songs and Ayres for one Voice to Sing to a Theorbo-Lute or Ba≈øs-Viol, being mo≈øt of the newe≈øt Songs ≈øung at Court, and at the Publick Theaters. 2 s. 6 d.
An Antidote again≈øt Melancholly, compounded of merry Ballads and Songs. Bound 2 s.
The Cabinet of Mirth, containing merry Tales, Je≈øts, and Bulls, being the Second Part of the Antidote again≈øt Melancholly. Bound 2 s.
